Now, I know this piece is propaganda, but I'm curious as to how much of it is true. I know I'd have trouble if I needed photo ID to vote in this country, it seems absurd to demand that you have to have formal ID in order to exercise your basic rights.

post_info.post_title: Are the Republicans trying to rig the mid terms?

Phunting

Well personally I think asking for ID is a totally reasonable idea. Especially in this country following the recent electoral fraud allegations. It is currently laughably easy to forge someone's vote, and I don't see attempts to curtail this as some sinister right wing conspiracy.
 
 This does strike me as typical of the kind of XXXX the Grauniad regularly whines on about.
Jo Bennett

But why should people have to learn to drive, a pretty expensive exercise, in order to vote? I was recently required to present ID bearing my name, signature and photograph. Fortunately as a student my NUS Extra card carries those details, but if I wasn't I would have had to fork out £80 I do not have for a passport. Few of the problems in Britain have involved people voting at the polling booth but postal ballots. ID is only a reasonable demand if everyone has ID or can obtain it easily for free.
Rovdak

I have to show a Government-approved photo ID when voting, the cheapest is the NIK, a 30 or so photo ID that I can use as legal ID in the EU as well as Norway and Iceland (I have a passport myself). To me it makes sense, I have to confirm my identity as citizen eligible to vote.
Big_Bear_Scot

If you look at the split in the UK though, it is the urban poor who are most strongly labour supporting, and the rural wealthy who are most strongly tory. The split is partly geographical as well as class, but those who live in urban areas are also less likely to be able to drive, as in urban areas it is an unnecessary luxury whereas in rural areas it is pretty much essential. The two compunded together mean that supporters of the right are more likely to have driving licences.

I worked as a voter registration officer for an election in Canada, and while virtually everyone had standard identification such as driver's licenses, we accepted pretty much anything people could come up with to prove their identity, no picture necessary.
 
 I was told to err on the side of letting anyone who wants to vote, vote. I only turned one person away because he literally could not produce anything at all with his name on it.
Winston Smith

I worked as a voter registration officer for an election in Canada, and while virtually everyone had standard identification such as driver's licenses, we accepted pretty much anything people could come up with to prove their identity, no picture necessary.
 
 I was told to err on the side of letting anyone who wants to vote, vote. I only turned one person away because he literally could not produce anything at all with his name on it.

 
 They do not ask for any id. you just go to the electoral table, and they look you up, once your name is found they cross it out and you cast your vote. We are not a police state. If taken to an extreme and it can happen, for if the numbers of those taking part dwindle to almost nothing is that society would have to abandon the democratic system and find another form of selecting its leaders?
When? None of our societies are really in a state where we have so few people voting to make workable system. It just means people actually interested in politics and who understand things vote. I know enough people who "don't do politics", to them a vote would be a random tick in a box, or worse nothing more than a Big Brother popularity contest, which it nearly is anyway. Voter apathy is imho brilliant, it allows politics to actually try and be about politics.
 
 How is forcing someone to vote, and therefore not allowing them to "protest" by not voting, more democratic than actually allowing people to choose what to do?

 Definitions of democracy:
 
 From wordnet.princeton.edu (found through google define)
 "
 # the political orientation of those who favor government by the people or by their elected representatives
 # a political system in which the supreme power lies in a body of citizens who can elect people to represent them
 # majority rule: the doctrine that the numerical majority of an organized group can make decisions binding on the whole group 
 "
 
 from wikipedia
 "
 The term democracy indicates a form of government where all the state's decisions are exercised directly or indirectly by a majority of its citizenry through a fair elective process. When these factors are met a government can be classified as such. This can apply to a multitude of government systems as these concepts transcend and often occur concomitantly with other types. 
 "
 
 Although the Constitution doesn't mention the term democracy, several times it mentions votes, such as 2/3, majority, etc. Representatives are (or are supposed to be) restricted to the powers set out by the Constitution. But they are elected representatives thus the United States IS a Democracy.

In answer to the thread question "Are the Repbulicans trying to rig the mid terms?" 
 The elections are over. The Democrats have retaken the house and senate. 
 I have yet to hear one accusation of voter fraud. Not one case. 
 But, the Republicans did rig the election. They conducted themselves as guttless wonders. They worked 2 days a week. They spent money as though they were Democrats. They did not police themselves as they would expect the rest of the world to do. They did not stand tall and support the president as they should have. They were mice hoping to not #### off the left as they know that doing that makes the leftwing media turn on them. Which to righteous men should be a badge of honor. Cowards who conduct themselves by not ####### people off go home, as they should.

 I will certainly agree that the republicans sunk themselves. The idea that "not standing up and supporting the presisdent" had much to do with their loss is ignoring an awful lot of what went on, though. 
 
 It was the republicans rubber stamping that XXXXXX policies for so many years that cost them the elections. They supported his idiotic Iraq fantasies, his assinine spending policies, and his absolutly tyrannical view on the constitution. Then, a few months before the elections, they finally look around and realize that Stalin was more popular with people he had stuck in death camps than George Buus was with the american people, so they try to shift course. After YEARS of rubber stamping everything the guy gave them and defending every moronic statement that came out of the guys mouth, they realize the guy is an idiot and if they want to get re-elected, they had better try to distance themselves from his stupidity.
 
 So, after sucking the guys nads for years, they finally jump up and say "we don't REALLY agree with him".
 
 Now, I will be the first to admit that the american people are a bunch of apathetic, gullible fools. Even the American public is not quite that stupid. 
 
 The republicans lost because they did a crappy job. They led the country off in the wrong direction, cost us trillions, and made us less safe, despite mounting a serious offensive against the bill of rights, which was supposed to protect us. 
 
 Hopefully, the republicans will pull their heads out of their butts and try to get back to actual conservative values. Then maybe they can get back into power. While watching them pick on gay people, strip civil rights, and blow money like drunken sailors in a whore house was interesting, it got old pretty quick.

Number 1. define how Americans are less safe. What event occurred after Sep. 11 that would prove that. 
 What economic event suggest that Bush had an adverse effect on Society.
 Deficit? America functioned with a massive deficit from the 40's to the 90's. Nobody noticed. 
 If your comparison of Bush's popularity to Stalin's after throwing Russians into death camps holds any truth, it would define the American people as the XXXXXX. 
 But, they are not much different than any other nation of fools, who's been led around by the nose by the media. 
 If Bush's war on terror does not go forward. If American's do not continue the war on Iraqi soil, it will come home. Then, you can whine about how safe you are. 
 Speaking of whining, what civil right have you lost? Please don't dig into your imagination. What can you not do now that you did before America was attacked? 
 Next, please give a clue as to what a leftist leadership will do that will bring safety and prosperity to you.
